title: Is NLP and hypnosis useful at all, or is it another pseudoscience like biokinesis? - Quora

response.answer_text: They are both. NLP and hypnosis are processes that have soft skills and process skills and have claims to effect on various physical, psychological, and behavioral tendencies. Most research on the clinical effectiveness do not fit Golden research standards. The science is always arguable because the volume of information is small and the definitions of NLP and hypnosis stretch far and wide. The argument for validity and reliability are contested in critical argument. Some of the sources of criticism are the sources of information and forum of publication. Some science now investigates and confirms the background processes that define a “hypnotic state”. Other research is more tangentially related to hypnosis and NLP such as brain wave activity and how it changes according to different stimuli. The process outcomes that are validated for hypnosis in medicine is in IBS and anaesthesia. A large portion of the teachings within a hypnosis or NLP training involve story telling and invariably include examples that can be dismissed as pseudoscience. The question of their effectiveness is experiential and there are clinical trials of hypnosis for various medical uses. NLP has less direct reference in research than hypnosis however it operates on equivalent principles. The presuppositions and assumptions are rooted in the experience of the human interaction and include concepts from personal and social psychology, emotion, and behavior. People may learn hypnosis or NLP for many different reasons and from many different sources. Some learn out of personal interest; while others learn for personal change; and yet others learn to influence others. The applications of hypnosis and NLP are also vast. From meditation to personal and professional development to guidance and therapy; the specializations in hypnosis and NLP depends on the person applying the skills. The short of it is that hypnosis and NLP are extremely useful tools in clinical settings because they Work and the principles are similar to those in psychotherapy.

When you consider that hypnosis has more than an 80% success rate when used to combat issues such as weight control, stress management, addiction management, memory retention, learning, pain control, blood pressure control, pregnancy and labour pains, psychological issues ranging from anxiety, OCD, phobias, social phobias and erectile dysfunction … … not to mention being used successfully by world-class athletes, of the caliber of Bradley Wiggins, Serena Williams, and Usain Bolt, to “get in the zone” during athletic competitions … … I’d say that hypnosis is a pretty solid and reliable technique. There is now even scientific medical evidence, based on brain scans of tranced patients, which proves that hypnosis has an actual physical effect on the neurons in the brains of entranced patients. There is evidence of hypnosis being used as a substitute for chemical anaesthesia in a number of different kinds of surgeries, ranging from brain surgery to vasectomies. Hypnosis works.
